content.description: A very obvious hand/fist crack on the left hand side of Prayer Wall.  Classic!  Very smooth and even, with good hand and footholds along its outer edge on the upper half
content.protection:
Three hand-sized hexes or cams. 

  If you are setting a TR, it might be prudent NOT to use the huge boulder sitting on top.  There are good stopper placements further back from the edge, and you already have lots of long webbing with you because this is Devils Lake.

content.description: The best route here at Prayer Wall!  Classic edges and sequence.  Starts at an incipient crack in the middle of the face, jogs left to pods in another incipient crack for a couple of moves, then moves back right to the 'sickle' shaped slot.  From here follow the gradually improving holds straight up along the crack.
The face left of the obvious hand/fist crack ("This is a Six?").
content.location: On the left hand end of Prayer Wall.

content.description: Vegetated cracks in a very clean wall.  Reachy and dirty.  Joins "Close Call" halfway up.
content.location: Just to the right of "Close Call"

content.description: Climb inside corner and slab. At 20 ft, switch to crack on the left wall. Finish right of summit block.
content.location: In the right corner, # 6 in Climber's Guide

content.description:
Short, but every move is sweet.  From the big tree in the gulley, scramble up and left to the steep crack.  Pull up to and over the overhang.  Continue up the too-thin crack. 

  If you have extra small fingers, this will probably be easier for you!
content.protection: Gear in your face whenever you want it.  Nuts and finger- and hand-sized cams.  Take a small (1/4 inch) cam for the last moves.
content.location: Right of Prayer Wall, scramble partway up the gulley.  It might be worth anchoring your belayer to something.

content.description:
A dihedral that will have you either stemming or squirming.  The initial section reminds me of "Lost Temple Crack." 

  For the upper portion, you can either finish left of the dihedral, or move right ... if you are leading, go right.
content.protection: Small, finger to thin-hand sized, plus something very thin for the dihedral crux (micronut or ballnut).
content.location: About 20 feet right of the main Prayer Wall area, left of the gulley.

content.description:
The crack that diagonals lower right to middle left.  Classic Devils Lake edges with less than you'd like for your feet.  It climbs a lot like the upper part of "Chicago". 

  You can stop at the shoulder where the crack ends, or continue up to the right.  It's easier to find an anchor up higher, under the cedar.
content.protection: Small to medium stoppers and a couple of cams in the 1-2 inch size.

pathTokens: East Bluff 02 - East of the Quarry

content.description: Prayer Wall is home to several great routes, plus a handful of 'pretty good' stuff.  The main wall has two well defined cracks ("This is a Six?" and "The Bishop"), and faces southeast.
